Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On their 20th birthday, identical twin 
astronauts volunteer for an experiment. Terra will remain on Earth, while Stella 
will board a spaceship. Stella’s ship will travel at 86.6% the 
speed of light to visit a star that is 10 
light-years away, then return to Earth at the same speed. As they prepare to part ways, the twins wonder what will happen 
when they’re reunited. Since a light year is exactly the distance
light can travel in a year, Stella’s journey should take 23 years. But from having studied 
special relativity, the twins know it’s not that simple. First of all, the faster an object moves 
through space, the slower it moves through time 
compared to an unmoving observer. This relationship can be quantified with 
something called the Lorentz factor, which is defined by this equation. And secondly, the length of a moving 
object as measured by an observer at rest will contract by the same factor. At 86.6% of the speed of light 
the Lorentz factor is 2, meaning time will pass twice as slowly 
aboard the spaceship. Of course, Stella won’t notice 
time slowing down. That’s because all time-based processes 
in the ship will slow down as well– clocks and electrical devices; Stella’s biological activities including 
her rate of aging and her perception of time itself. The only people who could notice time
on the moving spaceship passing slower for Stella would be observers in an inertial, 
or non-accelerating, reference frame– like Terra back on Earth. Thus, Terra concludes that when they meet
back on Earth, she’ll be older than Stella. But that’s just one way of 
looking at things. Because all movement is relative, Stella argues it would be just as valid to
say her spaceship will stand still while the rest of the universe, 
including Terra, moves around her. And in that case, time will pass twice as 
slowly for Terra, making Stella the older twin in the end. They can’t each be older than the other, 
so which one of them is right? This apparent contradiction is known as
the “Twin Paradox.” But it’s not really a paradox– just an example of how special relativity 
can be easily misunderstood. To test their theories in real-time, each of the twins agrees to send 
a burst of light to the other every time a year has passed for them. Unlike other objects, the speed of light 
is always constant regardless of an observer’s 
reference frame. A light burst sent from Earth will be 
measured at the same speed as a light burst sent from the spaceship, regardless of whether it’s on its 
outbound or return trip. So when one twin observes 
a burst of light, they’re measuring how long it took the 
other twin to experience a year passing, plus how long it took for light 
to travel between them. We can track what’s happening on a graph. The X axis marks distance from Earth, 
and the Y axis tracks the passage of time. From Terra’s perspective, her path will 
simply be a vertical line, with distance equal to zero and each tick on the line equivalent 
to a year as she perceives it. Stella’s path will stretch from the same 
origin to a point 11.5 years in time and 10 light-years in distance from Terra… before converging again at zero 
distance and 23 years’ time. At her first one-year mark, Terra will send a pulse of light from 
Earth towards Stella’s spaceship. Since light takes a year to travel 
one light-year, its path will be a 45-degree 
diagonal line. And because Stella is 
traveling away from it, by the time the light catches up to her, over 7 total years will have passed for
Terra, and over 4 for Stella. By the time Stella observes 
Terra’s second burst, she will already be on her return journey. But now, since she’s moving towards the 
source of the light, it will take less time to reach her, and she’ll observe the bursts 
more frequently. This means that Stella observes Terra 
aging slowly for the first half of her journey, but aging rapidly during the return half. Meanwhile for Stella, it seems as though 
Terra, the destination star, and the whole universe are 
moving around her. And because of length contraction, Stella observes the distance between 
them shrinking by a factor of 2. This means each leg of the trip will only 
take about six years from Stella’s perspective. When she sends the first signal to Earth, 
two years will have passed for Terra. Stella will send four more light bursts 
during her outbound journey, each one from farther away. By the time Terra observes the first pulse
from Stella's inbound journey, over 21 years will have passed for her. For the rest of Stella's return home, Terra receives multiple light 
bursts each year. Thus, Terra observes Stella aging slowly 
for about 90% of their 23 years apart, and aging rapidly during the last 10%. This asymmetry accounts for why the 
paradox isn’t really a paradox. Although each twin witnesses time both speeding up and slowing 
down for the other, Stella sees an even split, while Terra sees Stella aging slowly for 
most of the time they’re apart. This is consistent with each twin’s 
measurement of the space voyage, which takes 23 Earth years, but only 
11.5 as experienced aboard the ship. When the twins are reunited, Terra will be
43 years old, while Stella will be 31. Where Stella went wrong was her assumption that she and Terra had
equal claim to being inertial observers. To be an inertial observer, one has to 
maintain a constant speed and direction relative to the rest of the universe. Terra was at rest the entire time, 
so her velocity was a constant zero. But when Stella changed her direction 
for the return journey, she entered a different reference frame 
from the one she’d started in. Terra and Stella now both have a better
understanding of how spacetime works. And as twins who are eleven 
years apart in age, they’re a perfect example 
of special relativity.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If Stella measures Terra’s time passing slower than her own, Terra will see Stella’s time passing faster than her own. Stella will always measure her time passing at the same rate regardless of how fast she is moving. As long as Stella is moving in an inertial reference frame, she can claim that she is not moving and everything else is moving around her. The distance Stella measures between her origin and destination appears to decrease as her speed increases.
Options: A. If Stella measures Terra’s time passing slower than her own, Terra will see Stella’s time passing faster than her own., B. Stella will always measure her time passing at the same rate regardless of how fast she is moving., C. As long as Stella is moving in an inertial reference frame, she can claim that she is not moving and everything else is moving around her., D. The distance Stella measures between her origin and destination appears to decrease as her speed increases.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what speed will Stella's spaceship travel to visit a star that is 10 light-years away? Options: A. 50% the speed of light, B. 75% the speed of light, C. 86.6% the speed of light, D. 90% the speed of light Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the Lorentz factor at 86.6% of the speed of light? Options: A. 1, B. 1.5, C. 2, D. 2.5 Correct Option: None
Question 3: According to special relativity, what happens to time-based processes in a moving object? Options: A. They speed up, B. They slow down, C. They remain the same, D. They become unpredictable Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the "Twin Paradox" in special relativity? Options: A. A paradox where one twin ages faster than the other, B. A paradox where both twins age at the same rate, C. A paradox where time appears to slow down for one twin and speed up for the other, D. A paradox where the laws of physics are different for each twin Correct Option: None
Question 5: How will Terra and Stella test their theories in real-time? Options: A. By sending each other letters, B. By sending each other bursts of light, C. By communicating through a third party, D. By using a shared clock Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the speed of light regardless of an observer's reference frame? Options: A. Variable, B. Constant, C. Relative, D. Unpredictable Correct Option: None
Question 7: How long will it take for Stella's spaceship to reach the star and return to Earth from Terra's perspective? Options: A. 11.5 years, B. 20 years, C. 23 years, D. 30 years Correct Option: None
Question 8: How long will it take for Stella's spaceship to reach the star and return to Earth from Stella's perspective? Options: A. 11.5 years, B. 15 years, C. 20 years, D. 23 years Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the reason for the asymmetry in the twin paradox? Options: A. Stella's assumption that she and Terra had equal claim to being inertial observers, B. Terra's assumption that she was the only inertial observer, C. The difference in the speed of light between the two reference frames, D. The difference in the distance between the two reference frames Correct Option: None
Question 10: What will be the age difference between Terra and Stella when they are reunited? Options: A. 5 years, B. 10 years, C. 11 years, D. 12 years Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ based on question intent, options, and content.

The ground truth MCQ is about the twin paradox and the relative motion of the twins. It requires the test-taker to understand the concept of inertial reference frames and how time dilation occurs.

Among the generated MCQs, Question 9 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ. It asks about the reason for the asymmetry in the twin paradox, which is related to the concept of inertial reference frames.

Although the options in Question 9 do not exactly match the options in the ground truth MCQ, the question intent and content are similar.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is:

9

Note that the generated MCQs do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, and it is recommended to create new MCQs that more closely align with the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On their 20th birthday, identical twin 
astronauts volunteer for an experiment. Terra will remain on Earth, while Stella 
will board a spaceship. Stella’s ship will travel at 86.6% the 
speed of light to visit a star that is 10 
light-years away, then return to Earth at the same speed. As they prepare to part ways, the twins wonder what will happen 
when they’re reunited. Since a light year is exactly the distance
light can travel in a year, Stella’s journey should take 23 years. But from having studied

through space, the slower it moves through time 
compared to an unmoving observer. This relationship can be quantified with 
something called the Lorentz factor, which is defined by this equation. And secondly, the length of a moving

more frequently. This means that Stella observes Terra 
aging slowly for the first half of her journey, but aging rapidly during the return half. Meanwhile for Stella, it seems as though

moving around her. And because of length contraction, Stella observes the distance between

for about 90% of their 23 years apart, and aging rapidly during the last 10%. This asymmetry accounts for why the

down for the other, Stella sees an even split, while Terra sees Stella aging slowly for 
most of the time they’re apart. This is consistent with each twin’s 
measurement of the space voyage, which takes 23 Earth years, but only 
11.5 as experienced aboard the ship. When the twins are reunited, Terra will be
43 years old, while Stella will be 31. Where Stella went wrong was her assumption that she and Terra had
equal claim to being inertial observers. To be an inertial observer, one has to 
maintain a constant speed and direction relative to the rest of the universe. Terra was at rest the entire time, 
so her velocity was a constant zero. But when Stella changed her direction 
for the return journey, she entered a different reference frame 
from the one she’d started in. Terra and Stella now both have a better
understanding of how spacetime works. And as twins who are eleven 
years apart in age, they’re a perfect example 
of special relativity.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Stella is traveling on her spaceship at a velocity that makes the distance between the Earth and the destination star appear 80% the distance that Terra measures on Earth. What speed does Terra measure Stella traveling at as a fraction of the speed of light, c?
Options: A. 0.3c, B. 0.6c, C. 0.8c, D. 1.25c
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what speed will Stella's spaceship travel to visit a star that is 10 light-years away? Options: A. 50% the speed of light, B. 75% the speed of light, C. 86.6% the speed of light, D. 90% the speed of light Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the Lorentz factor at 86.6% of the speed of light? Options: A. 1, B. 1.5, C. 2, D. 2.5 Correct Option: None
Question 3: According to special relativity, what happens to time-based processes in a moving object? Options: A. They speed up, B. They slow down, C. They remain the same, D. They become unpredictable Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the "Twin Paradox" in special relativity? Options: A. A paradox where one twin ages faster than the other, B. A paradox where both twins age at the same rate, C. A paradox where time appears to slow down for one twin and speed up for the other, D. A paradox where the laws of physics are different for each twin Correct Option: None
Question 5: How will Terra and Stella test their theories in real-time? Options: A. By sending each other letters, B. By sending each other bursts of light, C. By communicating through a third party, D. By using a shared clock Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the speed of light regardless of an observer's reference frame? Options: A. Variable, B. Constant, C. Relative, D. Unpredictable Correct Option: None
Question 7: How long will it take for Stella's spaceship to reach the star and return to Earth from Terra's perspective? Options: A. 11.5 years, B. 20 years, C. 23 years, D. 30 years Correct Option: None
Question 8: How long will it take for Stella's spaceship to reach the star and return to Earth from Stella's perspective? Options: A. 11.5 years, B. 15 years, C. 20 years, D. 23 years Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the reason for the asymmetry in the twin paradox? Options: A. Stella's assumption that she and Terra had equal claim to being inertial observers, B. Terra's assumption that she was the only inertial observer, C. The difference in the speed of light between the two reference frames, D. The difference in the distance between the two reference frames Correct Option: None
Question 10: What will be the age difference between Terra and Stella when they are reunited? Options: A. 5 years, B. 10 years, C. 11 years, D. 12 years Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On their 20th birthday, identical twin 
astronauts volunteer for an experiment. Terra will remain on Earth, while Stella 
will board a spaceship. Stella’s ship will travel at 86.6% the 
speed of light to visit a star that is 10 
light-years away, then return to Earth at the same speed. As they prepare to part ways, the twins wonder what will happen 
when they’re reunited. Since a light year is exactly the distance
light can travel in a year, Stella’s journey should take 23 years. But from having studied 
special relativity, the twins know it’s not that simple. First of all, the faster an object moves 
through space, the slower it moves through time 
compared to an unmoving observer. This relationship can be quantified with 
something called the Lorentz factor, which is defined by this equation. And secondly, the length of a moving 
object as measured by an observer at rest will contract by the same factor. At 86.6% of the speed of light 
the Lorentz factor is 2, meaning time will pass twice as slowly 
aboard the spaceship. Of course, Stella won’t notice 
time slowing down. That’s because all time-based processes 
in the ship will slow down as well– clocks and electrical devices; Stella’s biological activities including 
her rate of aging and her perception of time itself. The only people who could notice time
on the moving spaceship passing slower for Stella would be observers in an inertial, 
or non-accelerating, reference frame– like Terra back on Earth. Thus, Terra concludes that when they meet
back on Earth, she’ll be older than Stella. But that’s just one way of 
looking at things. Because all movement is relative, Stella argues it would be just as valid to
say her spaceship will stand still while the rest of the universe, 
including Terra, moves around her. And in that case, time will pass twice as 
slowly for Terra, making Stella the older twin in the end. They can’t each be older than the other, 
so which one of them is right? This apparent contradiction is known as
the “Twin Paradox.” But it’s not really a paradox– just an example of how special relativity 
can be easily misunderstood. To test their theories in real-time, each of the twins agrees to send 
a burst of light to the other every time a year has passed for them. Unlike other objects, the speed of light 
is always constant regardless of an observer’s 
reference frame. A light burst sent from Earth will be 
measured at the same speed as a light burst sent from the spaceship, regardless of whether it’s on its 
outbound or return trip. So when one twin observes 
a burst of light, they’re measuring how long it took the 
other twin to experience a year passing, plus how long it took for light 
to travel between them. We can track what’s happening on a graph. The X axis marks distance from Earth, 
and the Y axis tracks the passage of time. From Terra’s perspective, her path will 
simply be a vertical line, with distance equal to zero and each tick on the line equivalent 
to a year as she perceives it. Stella’s path will stretch from the same 
origin to a point 11.5 years in time and 10 light-years in distance from Terra… before converging again at zero 
distance and 23 years’ time. At her first one-year mark, Terra will send a pulse of light from 
Earth towards Stella’s spaceship. Since light takes a year to travel 
one light-year, its path will be a 45-degree 
diagonal line. And because Stella is 
traveling away from it, by the time the light catches up to her, over 7 total years will have passed for
Terra, and over 4 for Stella. By the time Stella observes 
Terra’s second burst, she will already be on her return journey. But now, since she’s moving towards the 
source of the light, it will take less time to reach her, and she’ll observe the bursts 
more frequently. This means that Stella observes Terra 
aging slowly for the first half of her journey, but aging rapidly during the return half. Meanwhile for Stella, it seems as though 
Terra, the destination star, and the whole universe are 
moving around her. And because of length contraction, Stella observes the distance between 
them shrinking by a factor of 2. This means each leg of the trip will only 
take about six years from Stella’s perspective. When she sends the first signal to Earth, 
two years will have passed for Terra. Stella will send four more light bursts 
during her outbound journey, each one from farther away. By the time Terra observes the first pulse
from Stella's inbound journey, over 21 years will have passed for her. For the rest of Stella's return home, Terra receives multiple light 
bursts each year. Thus, Terra observes Stella aging slowly 
for about 90% of their 23 years apart, and aging rapidly during the last 10%. This asymmetry accounts for why the 
paradox isn’t really a paradox. Although each twin witnesses time both speeding up and slowing 
down for the other, Stella sees an even split, while Terra sees Stella aging slowly for 
most of the time they’re apart. This is consistent with each twin’s 
measurement of the space voyage, which takes 23 Earth years, but only 
11.5 as experienced aboard the ship. When the twins are reunited, Terra will be
43 years old, while Stella will be 31. Where Stella went wrong was her assumption that she and Terra had
equal claim to being inertial observers. To be an inertial observer, one has to 
maintain a constant speed and direction relative to the rest of the universe. Terra was at rest the entire time, 
so her velocity was a constant zero. But when Stella changed her direction 
for the return journey, she entered a different reference frame 
from the one she’d started in. Terra and Stella now both have a better
understanding of how spacetime works. And as twins who are eleven 
years apart in age, they’re a perfect example 
of special relativity.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Stella is traveling on her spaceship at a velocity that makes the distance between the Earth and the destination star appear 80% the distance that Terra measures on Earth. When Stella measures 200 seconds pass on the spaceship, how many seconds have passed for Terra on Earth?
Options: A. 160 seconds, B. 200 seconds, C. 250 seconds, D. 400 seconds
Correct Option: C

Question 1: At what speed will Stella's spaceship travel to visit a star that is 10 light-years away? Options: A. 50% the speed of light, B. 75% the speed of light, C. 86.6% the speed of light, D. 90% the speed of light Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the Lorentz factor at 86.6% of the speed of light? Options: A. 1, B. 1.5, C. 2, D. 2.5 Correct Option: None
Question 3: According to special relativity, what happens to time-based processes in a moving object? Options: A. They speed up, B. They slow down, C. They remain the same, D. They become unpredictable Correct Option: None

A paradox where time appears to slow down for one twin and speed up for the other, D. A paradox where the laws of physics are different for each twin Correct Option: None

Question 6: What is the speed of light regardless of an observer's reference frame? Options: A. Variable, B. Constant, C. Relative, D. Unpredictable Correct Option: None
Question 7: How long will it take for Stella's spaceship to reach the star and return to Earth from Terra's perspective? Options: A. 11.5 years, B. 20 years, C. 23 years, D. 30 years Correct Option: None
Question 8: How long will it take for Stella's spaceship to reach the star and return to Earth from Stella's perspective? Options: A. 11.5 years, B. 15 years, C. 20 years, D. 23 years Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the reason for the asymmetry in the twin paradox? Options: A. Stella's assumption that she and Terra had equal claim to being inertial observers, B. Terra's assumption that she was the only inertial observer, C. The difference in the speed of light between the two reference frames, D. The difference in the distance between the two reference frames Correct Option: None

On their 20th birthday, identical twin 
astronauts volunteer for an experiment. Terra will remain on Earth, while Stella

equal claim to being inertial observers. To be an inertial observer, one has to 
maintain a constant speed and direction relative to the rest of the universe. Terra was at rest the entire time, 
so her velocity was a constant zero. But when Stella changed her direction 
for the return journey, she entered a different reference frame 
from the one she’d started in. Terra and Stella now both have a better
understanding of how spacetime works. And as twins who are eleven 
years apart in age, they’re a perfect example 
of special relativity.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Time, length, and mass are measured with respect to an inertial reference frame in special relativity. Which of the following statements are not true about an inertial reference frame?
Options: A. It has a constant speed., B. If moving, its direction is constant., C. It is possible to stay in the same inertial reference frame during a round trip voyage., D. To an observer in an inertial reference frame, the length and mass of objects, and the passage of time are constant.
Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why is the “Twin Paradox” not really a paradox?
Options: A. Both Terra and Stella see each other aging first slowly then aging quickly., B. Terra observes Stella aging slowly for most of their time apart, while Stella measures Terra aging slowly for just half of their time apart., C. When Stella is traveling in her spaceship, the distance between Earth and the destination star appears less than it does to Terra., D. Stella aged the same amount as Terra on the way to the destination star but traveled back in time on her way back to Earth.
Correct Option: B

Although the options and wording are not identical, the intent and content of Question 9 are similar to the ground truth MCQ. Both questions address the reason why the "Twin Paradox" is not a paradox, and both involve the concept of inertial observers. However, it's worth noting that the correct option in Question 9 is not explicitly stated, and the wording of the options is different from the ground truth MCQ.

A more ideal match would be a generated MCQ with options that directly address the asymmetry in the twin paradox, such as Terra observing Stella aging slowly for most of their time apart, while Stella measures Terra aging slowly for just half of their time apart. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in this regard.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 9.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
“A few dozen hours can affect the 
outcome of whole lifetimes/ And that when they do, 
those few dozen hours, like the salvaged remains 
of a burned clock… must be resurrected from the ruins 
and examined.” This is the premise of Arundhati Roy’s 
1997 novel "The God of Small Things." Set in a town in Kerala, India called 
Ayemenem, the story revolves around fraternal 
twins Rahel and Estha, who are separated for 23 years 
after the fateful few dozen hours in which their cousin drowns, their 
mother’s illicit affair is revealed, and her lover is murdered. While the book is set at the point of 
Rahel and Estha’s reunion, the narrative takes place mostly in
the past, reconstructing the details around the tragic events that 
led to their separation. Roy’s rich language and masterful 
storytelling earned her the prestigious Booker prize 
for "The God of Small Things." In the novel, she interrogates the culture
of her native India, including its social mores 
and colonial history. One of her focuses is the caste system, a way of classifying people by hereditary 
social class that is thousands of years old. By the mid-20th century, the original four castes associated 
with specific occupations had been divided into 
some 3000 sub-castes. Though the caste system was 
Constitutionally abolished in 1950, it continued to shape 
social life in India, routinely marginalizing people 
of lower castes. In the novel, Rahel and Estha have a 
close relationship with Velutha, a worker in their family’s pickle factory and member of the so-called 
“untouchable” caste. When Velutha and the twins’ mother, Ammu,
embark on an affair, they violate what Roy describes as the 
“love laws” forbidding intimacy between 
different castes. Roy warns that the tragic consequences 
of their relationship “would lurk forever in ordinary things,” 
like “coat hangers,” “the tar on roads,” and “the absence of words.” Roy’s writing makes constant use of these 
ordinary things, bringing lush detail to even the most 
tragic moments. The book opens at the funeral of the 
twins’ half-British cousin Sophie after her drowning. As the family mourns, lilies curl and 
crisp in the hot church. A baby bat crawls up a funeral sari. Tears drip from a chin like 
raindrops from a roof. The novel forays into the past to explore
the characters’ struggles to operate in a world 
where they don’t quite fit, alongside their nation’s 
political turmoil. Ammu struggles not to lash out at her 
beloved children when she feels particularly trapped in her
parents’ small-town home, where neighbors judge and shun her 
for being divorced. Velutha, meanwhile, balances his affair
with Ammu and friendship with the twins not only with his employment 
to their family, but also with his membership to a 
budding communist countermovement to Indira Ghandi’s “Green Revolution.” In the 1960s, the misleadingly named 
“Green Revolution” introduced chemical fertilizers 
and pesticides and the damming of rivers to India. While these policies produced high-yield 
crops that staved off famine, they also forced people from lower castes 
off their land and caused widespread 
environmental damage. When the twins return to Ayemenem 
as adults, the consequences of the Green Revolution 
are all around them. The river that was bursting with life 
in their childhood greets them “with a ghastly skull’s smile,
with holes where teeth had been, and a limp hand raised 
from a hospital bed.” As Roy probes the depths of human 
experience, she never loses sight of the way her 
characters are shaped by the time and the place where they live. In the world of "The God of Small Things," “Various kinds of despair competed 
for primacy… personal despair could never be 
desperate enough... personal turmoil dropped by at the wayside
shrine of the vast, violent, circling, driving, ridiculous, insane, unfeasible 
public turmoil of a nation.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The name of the family business in the novel is
Options: A. Paradise Pickles and Preserves, B. Pappachi’s Pickles and Peanuts, C. Rahel’s Raisins and Raspberries, D. Velutha’s Vitamins
Correct Option: A

Question 4: What is the name of the worker in the twins' family's pickle factory who is a member of the "untouchable" caste? Options: A. Velutha., B. Rahel., C. Estha., D. Ammu. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the term used by Roy to describe the laws that forbid intimacy between different castes? Options: A. Love laws., B. Caste laws., C. Social laws., D. Moral laws. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the Indian prime minister who introduced the Green Revolution in the 1960s? Options: A. Indira Gandhi., B. Jawaharlal Nehru., C. Mahatma Gandhi., D. Rajiv Gandhi. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the impact of the Green Revolution on the environment and society? Options: A. It produced high-yield crops and improved the standard of living for many Indians., B. It forced people from lower castes off their land and caused widespread environmental damage., C. It had no significant impact on the environment and society., D. It improved the economy but had no impact on the environment. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the award won by Arundhati Roy for her novel "The God of Small Things"? Options: A. Booker Prize., B. Pulitzer Prize., C. National Book Award., D. Nobel Prize in Literature. Correct Option: None
Question 9: How does Roy describe the river that was once bursting with life in the twins' childhood? Options: A. As a beautiful and serene river., B. As a polluted and damaged river., C. As a river with a "ghastly skull's smile, with holes where teeth had been, and a limp hand raised from a hospital bed.", D. As a river that has not changed over time. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the theme of the novel "The God of Small Things"? Options: A. The struggle for independence in India., B. The impact of the Green Revolution on the environment and society., C. The exploration of the human experience and the way individuals are shaped by time and place., D. The story of a family's struggles and triumphs. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Question 4: What is the name of the worker in the twins' family's pickle factory who is a member of the "untouchable" caste?

outcome of whole lifetimes/ And that when they do, 
those few dozen hours, like the salvaged remains 
of a burned clock… must be resurrected from the ruins 
and examined.” This is the premise of Arundhati Roy’s

Ayemenem, the story revolves around fraternal

led to their separation. Roy’s rich language and masterful

for "The God of Small Things." In the novel, she interrogates the culture

It improved the economy but had no impact on the environment. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the award won by Arundhati Roy for her novel "The God of Small Things"? Options: A. Booker Prize., B. Pulitzer Prize., C. National Book Award., D. Nobel Prize in Literature. Correct Option: None
Question 9: How does Roy describe the river that was once bursting with life in the twins' childhood? Options: A. As a beautiful and serene river., B. As a polluted and damaged river., C. As a river with a "ghastly skull's smile, with holes where teeth had been, and a limp hand raised from a hospital bed.", D. As a river that has not changed over time. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the theme of the novel "The God of Small Things"? Options: A. The struggle for independence in India., B. The impact of the Green Revolution on the environment and society., C. The exploration of the human experience and the way individuals are shaped by time and place., D. The story of a family's struggles and triumphs. Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
“A few dozen hours can affect the 
outcome of whole lifetimes/ And that when they do, 
those few dozen hours, like the salvaged remains 
of a burned clock… must be resurrected from the ruins 
and examined.” This is the premise of Arundhati Roy’s 
1997 novel "The God of Small Things." Set in a town in Kerala, India called 
Ayemenem, the story revolves around fraternal 
twins Rahel and Estha, who are separated for 23 years 
after the fateful few dozen hours in which their cousin drowns, their 
mother’s illicit affair is revealed, and her lover is murdered. While the book is set at the point of 
Rahel and Estha’s reunion, the narrative takes place mostly in
the past, reconstructing the details around the tragic events that 
led to their separation. Roy’s rich language and masterful 
storytelling earned her the prestigious Booker prize 
for "The God of Small Things." In the novel, she interrogates the culture
of her native India, including its social mores 
and colonial history. One of her focuses is the caste system, a way of classifying people by hereditary 
social class that is thousands of years old. By the mid-20th century, the original four castes associated 
with specific occupations had been divided into 
some 3000 sub-castes. Though the caste system was 
Constitutionally abolished in 1950, it continued to shape 
social life in India, routinely marginalizing people 
of lower castes. In the novel, Rahel and Estha have a 
close relationship with Velutha, a worker in their family’s pickle factory and member of the so-called 
“untouchable” caste. When Velutha and the twins’ mother, Ammu,
embark on an affair, they violate what Roy describes as the 
“love laws” forbidding intimacy between 
different castes. Roy warns that the tragic consequences 
of their relationship “would lurk forever in ordinary things,” 
like “coat hangers,” “the tar on roads,” and “the absence of words.” Roy’s writing makes constant use of these 
ordinary things, bringing lush detail to even the most 
tragic moments. The book opens at the funeral of the 
twins’ half-British cousin Sophie after her drowning. As the family mourns, lilies curl and 
crisp in the hot church. A baby bat crawls up a funeral sari. Tears drip from a chin like 
raindrops from a roof. The novel forays into the past to explore
the characters’ struggles to operate in a world 
where they don’t quite fit, alongside their nation’s 
political turmoil. Ammu struggles not to lash out at her 
beloved children when she feels particularly trapped in her
parents’ small-town home, where neighbors judge and shun her 
for being divorced. Velutha, meanwhile, balances his affair
with Ammu and friendship with the twins not only with his employment 
to their family, but also with his membership to a 
budding communist countermovement to Indira Ghandi’s “Green Revolution.” In the 1960s, the misleadingly named 
“Green Revolution” introduced chemical fertilizers 
and pesticides and the damming of rivers to India. While these policies produced high-yield 
crops that staved off famine, they also forced people from lower castes 
off their land and caused widespread 
environmental damage. When the twins return to Ayemenem 
as adults, the consequences of the Green Revolution 
are all around them. The river that was bursting with life 
in their childhood greets them “with a ghastly skull’s smile,
with holes where teeth had been, and a limp hand raised 
from a hospital bed.” As Roy probes the depths of human 
experience, she never loses sight of the way her 
characters are shaped by the time and the place where they live. In the world of "The God of Small Things," “Various kinds of despair competed 
for primacy… personal despair could never be 
desperate enough... personal turmoil dropped by at the wayside
shrine of the vast, violent, circling, driving, ridiculous, insane, unfeasible 
public turmoil of a nation.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does Sophie Mol die?
Options: A. Velutha strangles her, B. Car accident, C. Suicide, D. Drowns
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Väinämöinen’s home is located in
Options: A. Pohjola, B. Kalevala, C. The North
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of the powerful bard and sage who washed up on the shores of Pohjola? Options: A. Seppo Ilmarinen, B. Väinämöinen, C. Lemminkäinen, D. Ahti Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the name of the ruler of Pohjola, described as "the gap-tooth hag of the North"? Options: A. Louhi, B. Väinämöinen, C. Ilmarinen, D. Lemminkäinen Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name of the artifact that Louhi demanded as a reward for returning Väinämöinen home? Options: A. The Kantele, B. The Sampo, C. The Sky-Dome, D. The Forge Correct Option: None
Question 4: Who was the only person capable of crafting the Sampo? Options: A. Väinämöinen, B. Ilmarinen, C. Lemminkäinen, D. Louhi Correct Option: None
Question 5: What were the three mills that Ilmarinen crafted on the sides of the Sampo? Options: A. A grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill, B. A grain mill, a flour mill, and a sugar mill, C. A salt mill, a money mill, and a spice mill, D. A grain mill, a salt mill, and a spice mill Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why did Ilmarinen refuse to go to Pohjola initially? Options: A. He was afraid of Louhi, B. He was afraid of the journey, C. He considered Pohjola a land of witches and man-eaters, D. He was busy with other tasks Correct Option: None
Question 7: How did Väinämöinen trick Ilmarinen into going to Pohjola? Options: A. He promised him a reward, B. He convinced him of the importance of the task, C. He tricked him into climbing a giant tree and summoned a storm to carry him to Pohjola, D. He forced him to go Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the outcome of Lemminkäinen's singing after they retrieved the Sampo? Options: A. It put the Pohjolan army to sleep, B. It woke up a nearby crane, which alerted the Pohjolan army, C. It had no effect, D. It made the Sampo work faster Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happened to the Sampo at the end of the story? Options: A. It was taken back by Louhi, B. It was kept by Väinämöinen and Ilmarinen, C. It was shattered into pieces and sank to the ocean floor, D. It was hidden in a mountain Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the story, what do the remnants of the Sampo do to this day? Options: A. They grind salt for the seas, B. They produce wealth for Pohjola, C. They remain hidden in a mountain, D. They have no effect Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall intent and context, I would say that Question 2 is the most similar generated MCQ, as it also deals with identifying a specific entity (Louhi) associated with a particular location (Pohjola).

However, a more relevant question would be one that asks about the location of Väinämöinen's home. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match this intent.

If I had to choose, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is not available in the provided options.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does Louhi promise to Ilmarinen for crafting the Sampo?
Options: A. Her daughter’s hand, B. A party with extravagant hospitality, C. A new boat
Correct Option: A

back to health but demanded a reward for

indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend

ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that

pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from

a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where does Louhi hide the Sampo?
Options: A. In the depth of the ocean, B. Under her house, C. In Kalevala, D. Inside a mountain
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does Väinämöinen make Louhi’s army fall asleep?
Options: A. by swinging his magic wand, B. by blowing magic powder on them, C. by playing his magic kantele
Correct Option: C

Question 6: Why did Ilmarinen refuse to go to Pohjola initially? Options: A. He was afraid of Louhi, B. He was afraid of the journey, C. He considered Pohjola a land of witches and man-eaters, D. He was busy with other tasks Correct Option: None

back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that

the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Neon lighting was first commercially produced in which country?
Options: A. Italy, B. United States, C. France, D. England
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main factor that contributed to the growth and development of Las Vegas, Nevada, in the 1930s? Options: A. The construction of the Hoover Dam, B. The discovery of oil in the area, C. The expansion of the railroad system, D. The growth of the agriculture industry Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who is credited with developing the techniques for capturing and making neon gas glow? Options: A. Georges Claude, B. Thomas Edison, C. Nikola Tesla, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the process by which neon signs are made to glow? Options: A. Heating the gas to a high temperature, B. Passing a high voltage current through the tube, C. Exposing the gas to ultraviolet light, D. Cooling the gas to a low temperature Correct Option: None
Question 4: What happens to the electrons in the neon atoms when a neon sign is turned on? Options: A. They slow down and lose energy, B. They accelerate and break free of their orbits, C. They remain unchanged, D. They disappear Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the result of the excited electrons falling back to their normal energy levels? Options: A. The emission of photons, or particles of light, B. The absorption of photons, or particles of light, C. The creation of heat, D. The destruction of the neon atoms Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many different gases are commonly used in the production of neon signs? Options: A. 3, B. 5, C. 7, D. 10 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the typical lifespan of a neon sign before the gas depletes? Options: A. 10 years, B. 20 years, C. 40 years, D. 60 years Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why were most neon signs created by local neon shops rather than being shipped over long distances? Options: A. Because of the high cost of shipping, B. Because of the fragile nature of the glass tubes, C. Because of the complexity of the installation process, D. Because of the limited availability of materials Correct Option: None
Question 9: What led to the decline of neon sign production after World War II? Options: A. The rise of digital signage, B. The increasing cost of materials, C. The availability of inexpensive plastics, D. The decline of the advertising industry Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the current state of the craft of tube bending? Options: A. It has been largely automated, B. It has been replaced by digital signage, C. It has remained relatively unchanged, D. It has become a lost art Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: Who is credited with developing the techniques for capturing and making neon gas glow? Options: A. Georges Claude, B. Thomas Edison, C. Nikola Tesla, D. Albert Einstein.

Although the question is not an exact match, it is related to the development of neon lighting and mentions Georges Claude, who is also mentioned in the transcript as the French inventor who came up with techniques to capture and make neon gas glow. The ground truth MCQ asks about the country where neon lighting was first commercially produced, and according to the transcript, Georges Claude developed the techniques in France.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of

Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was

a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which one of these gasses is not used in neon sign making?
Options: A. Xenon, B. Floron, C. Helium, D. Argon
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Excess energy from excited electrons are carried away by particles of light called?
Options: A. photons, B. molecules, C. gamma rays, D. x-rays
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main factor that contributed to the growth and development of Las Vegas, Nevada, in the 1930s? Options: A. The construction of the Hoover Dam, B. The discovery of oil in the area, C. The expansion of the railroad system, D. The growth of the agriculture industry Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who is credited with developing the techniques for capturing and making neon gas glow? Options: A. Georges Claude, B. Thomas Edison, C. Nikola Tesla, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the process by which neon signs are made to glow? Options: A. Heating the gas to a high temperature, B. Passing a high voltage current through the tube, C. Exposing the gas to ultraviolet light, D. Cooling the gas to a low temperature Correct Option: None
Question 4: What happens to the electrons in the neon atoms when a neon sign is turned on? Options: A. They slow down and lose energy, B. They accelerate and break free of their orbits, C. They remain unchanged, D. They disappear Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the result of the excited electrons falling back to their normal energy levels? Options: A. The emission of photons, or particles of light, B. The absorption of photons, or particles of light, C. The creation of heat, D. The destruction of the neon atoms Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many different gases are commonly used in the production of neon signs? Options: A. 3, B. 5, C. 7, D. 10 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the typical lifespan of a neon sign before the gas depletes? Options: A. 10 years, B. 20 years, C. 40 years, D. 60 years Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why were most neon signs created by local neon shops rather than being shipped over long distances? Options: A. Because of the high cost of shipping, B. Because of the fragile nature of the glass tubes, C. Because of the complexity of the installation process, D. Because of the limited availability of materials Correct Option: None
Question 9: What led to the decline of neon sign production after World War II? Options: A. The rise of digital signage, B. The increasing cost of materials, C. The availability of inexpensive plastics, D. The decline of the advertising industry Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the current state of the craft of tube bending? Options: A. It has been largely automated, B. It has been replaced by digital signage, C. It has remained relatively unchanged, D. It has become a lost art Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What is the result of the excited electrons falling back to their normal energy levels? Options: A. The emission of photons, or particles of light, B. The absorption of photons, or particles of light, C. The creation of heat, D. The destruction of the neon atoms.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions are asking about the outcome of excited electrons returning to their normal energy levels, and both have an option that mentions photons or particles of light.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5.

causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any

around the world.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 5

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of

Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was

separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial

and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections

behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from

causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any

them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by

on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.
